title: Mythbusting
section: The most common questions Psych Students get asked
text: The most common questions Psych Students get asked

title: Mythbusting
text:
Introduce yourself, Gordon

Unfortunately, none of the interesting psychologists are here today.
So you are stuck with me.
I am sorry to say that I spend lots of my time lecturing Research Methods and Statistics.
We take that seriously here at Goldsmiths.

title: Mythbusting
section: We are just about to introduce next year’s Y2 research topics
text:
We are just about to introduce next year’s Y2 research topics

Independent choice of topics
Work as a group
Run a real exxperiment using Qual and Quant techniques
And yes, Analyse the data!

title: Mythbusting
section: This year was a bit of a nightmare…
text:
This year was a bit of a nightmare…
Let me tell you why!

title: Mythbusting
text: Can you read my mind?

title: Mythbusting
text: Mind-reading for real

title: Mythbusting
text: Die in the cup task

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Science of Mind Reading

Psychological research reveals we can detect subtle nonverbal cues that appear like mind reading
Psychologists study subconscious communication through microexpressions and body language
Professional “mind readers” utilize techniques like cold reading, warm reading, and hot reading
Brain imaging studies show how we predict others’ intentions through mirror neurons and theory of mind

title: Mythbusting
text:
Techniques Behind “Mind Reading”


Scientific Explanations

Unconscious behavioral cues
Implicit pattern recognition
Skilled observation of reactions
Statistical guessing with feedback


Real-World Applications

Clinical psychology assessments
Law enforcement interrogations
Marketing and consumer research
Human-computer interaction design

title: Mythbusting
text: Are you profiling me?

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Psychology of Environmental Profiling

Research shows personal spaces contain “behavioral residue” that reveals personality traits
Psychologists can analyze bedrooms, offices, and social media profiles for accurate personality insights
Gosling’s research demonstrates how possessions and environment reflect our “extended self”
The field of psychogeography explores how personal spaces both shape and reflect identity

title: Mythbusting
section: What Your Stuff Says About You
text:
What Your Stuff Says About You


What We Can Actually Tell

Conscientiousness from organization
Openness from variety of books/music
Extraversion from memorabilia
Emotional stability from photo content


Ethical Considerations

Consent and privacy boundaries
Avoiding stereotyping
Cultural context differences
Responsible use of information

title: Mythbusting
text: Can you seduce anyone?

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Science of Rapport Building

Psychological research identifies specific techniques that build authentic connection
Mirroring and behavioral synchrony create unconscious feelings of affinity
Self-disclosure and active listening promote oxytocin release and interpersonal bonding
Cialdini’s principles of influence explain persuasion effects in social contexts

title: Mythbusting
text:
Building Genuine Connection


Empirically-Validated Techniques

Maintained eye contact (70% listening)
Subtle mirroring of posture and speech
Asking follow-up questions
Using person’s name appropriately


Beyond Manipulation

Authentic interest vs. manipulation
Ethics of interpersonal influence
Building meaningful relationships
Applying research responsibly

title: Mythbusting
text: Do you like People Watching?

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Science of Social Observation

People-watching is a sophisticated cognitive process studied in social perception research
Psychologists analyze “third-party encounters” to understand how we interpret social interactions
We form accurate impressions about relationships, status, and intentions within seconds
Brain studies reveal specialized neural networks dedicated to processing social dynamics

title: Mythbusting
section: How We Make Sense of Social Interactions
text:
How We Make Sense of Social Interactions


What We Can Detect

Relationship types (friends vs. strangers)
Power dynamics and social status
Romantic interest and attraction
Cultural norms and violations


Research Applications

Clinical assessments (e.g., autism)
Cross-cultural understanding
Artificial intelligence development
Urban planning and public spaces


https://huggingface.co/spaces/LittleMonkeyLab/All_a_bit_emotional

title: Mythbusting
section: Can you do tricks like Derren Brown?
text: Can you do tricks like Derren Brown?

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Psychology of Cold Reading

Cold reading uses psychological principles to create illusion of mind reading or clairvoyance
Techniques include Barnum statements, observation, and probability-based guessing
Psychologists study these methods to understand belief formation and cognitive biases
The ideomotor effect explains unconscious movements in techniques like pendulum swinging

title: Mythbusting
text: The Science Behind the Performance

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Science Behind the Performance 2


Psychological Mechanisms

Confirmation bias in interpretation
Subjective validation effects
Availability heuristics
The Forer (Barnum) effect


Critical Thinking Tools

Distinguishing skill from deception
Understanding suggestibility
Recognizing statistical tricks
Ethical entertainment vs. exploitation

title: Mythbusting
text: Can you Sherlock me?

title: Mythbusting
text:
The Science of Personality Prediction


Research shows personality traits can be predicted from behavioral patterns and preferences
The “Big Five” traits provide a scientific framework for understanding stable dimensions
Digital footprints on social media can reveal personality with surprising accuracy
Behavioral economics uses “nudges” based on personality insights to influence decisions

title: Mythbusting
text:
Predicting Personality from Behavior


What Science Can Actually Predict

Career preferences from personality traits
Consumer choices from values
Social behavior from attachment style
Digital behavior from cognitive style


MINDSPACE Framework

Messenger: who communicates matters
Incentives: response to rewards/penalties
Norms: influence of social expectations
Defaults: tendency to accept preset options
Salience: attention to novel/relevant items

title: Mythbusting
text:
Just because we are

Debunking myths in human behavior
Understanding the ethics of influence and perception
Thinking Critically about popular psychological claims
How to appreciate the complexity of the human mind

Doesn’t mean we have to be boring, and not use cool toys!

Psychology at Goldsmiths

title: MarshMallows
section: Overview of Y1 Psychology at Goldsmiths
text:
Overview of Y1 Psychology at Goldsmiths


Term 1 Modules - Introduction to Psychology - Research Methods & Statistics I - Biological & Comparative Approaches - Cognitive Psychology

Term 2 Modules - Social Psychology - Developmental Psychology - Individual Differences - Applied Psychology


Emphasize our unique strengths: - Critical approach to psychology - Integration of scientific rigor with creative thinking - Strong focus on research skills from day one

title: MarshMallows
text:
Research Methods Preview
This challenge demonstrates core elements of psychological research:


Variables:
Independent (group composition)
Dependent (tower height, completion)
Control (same materials, instructions)
Observation methods:
Structured observation
Behavioral coding
Process analysis
Data analysis:
Quantitative (height measurements)
Qualitative (group dynamics)

title: MarshMallows
text:
Observer Roles
Some of you will be observers rather than participants:


Communication patterns:
Who speaks? How often? Who listens?
Verbal vs. non-verbal communication
Decision-making processes:
How are ideas generated and evaluated?
Is there evidence of groupthink?
Leadership emergence:
Formal vs. informal leadership
Leadership styles (directive, participative)
Conflict resolution:
How are disagreements handled?
Constructive vs. destructive conflict

title: MarshMallows
text:
Post-Challenge Analysis
Tuckman’s Stages of Group Development


Forming: Orientation, testing boundaries
Storming: Conflict, resistance to task demands
Norming: Development of group cohesion
Performing: Functional role relatedness
Adjourning: Completion and disengagement

title: MarshMallows
text:
Cognitive Biases in Action






What we observed








Planning fallacy: Groups overestimated what they could accomplish
Functional fixedness: Limited vision of how materials could be used
Overconfidence bias: Initial certainty vs. final outcomes
Sunk cost fallacy: Continuing with failing approaches

text:

Time pressure effects on divergent thinking
Impact of evaluation apprehension
Stress responses: Fight, flight, or freeze in team contexts

title: MarshMallows
text:
The Kindergarten Advantage






Why children often outperform business students:








Rapid prototyping - testing early and often
No status management or impression concerns
Learning through play - less fear of failure
Less fixated on “one right way” to solve problems
Natural collaboration without hierarchy

Taking a stream subject: Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology, Cognitive Neuroscience

Departmental research talks
4-year degree with placement in 3rd year: Staff support you to secure placements in clinical / social care / educational / forensic

You choose the assessment format: essay, video, music, poster, audio presentation

Choose modules from other Departments across college: sociology, anthropology, music, computing, therapeutic studies, management school etc
You can also choose one or both of your electives from Psychology

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Welcome!

Psychology at Goldsmiths
Where science meets creativity

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Our ethos

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
About the Programme


Accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS). Achieving at least 50% on all modules makes you eligible for graduate membership of the BPS.
Underpinned by a bio-psycho-social model to explain how human behaviour is influenced by a complex mix of biological, social, environmental & psychological factors.
Develops understanding of applications of psychology and transferable skills for graduate-level employment by helping you to:

Critically assess evidence to develop and deliver creative, coherent, effective and ethical plans for changing practice and policy in an uncertain world.
Balance personal experience and perspective with scientific evidence to inform critical enquiry and public policy.

Taught in modules that connect with one another; some teaching in blocks:

Lectures, seminars, tutorials, independent learning and active learning strategies

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Pedagogy

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Year one Term one

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Year one Term two

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Year one Term three

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Personal and Professional Development




Every student has a Personal Tutor who will facilitate these tutorials
Aims to enable empowered, independent & interdependent learners
Pilot PPD programme in 2023/4 co-created with two third year students
Student Advisory Group reviewed whole curriculum, including PPD
In 2024/5

PPD connected to modular content and careers service
Assessed through portfolio of activities including guided reflections
Another Student Advisory Group will be developed

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Research Methods & Statistics
This module offers the nuts and bolts of conducting and interpreting different kinds of research.
These fundamental research skills are highly valued by graduate employers. Whether you want to be a psychologist, a research scientist, an entrepreneur or an Olympic athlete, developing the skills to conduct quality research and analyse data will serve you well.
You will be assessed via: * Lab-book of exercises – practice works! * 2 lab reports * In person multiple-choice exam

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Mental Health and Wellbeing
This module offers an introduction to psychological wellbeing and the emotional experience of being human.
Assessments are designed to help you connect psychological theory, scientific evidence and your personal development now and in the future.
You will be assessed via: * Evidence-based action plan for student wellbeing * Written description of a behavioural experiment; applying psychological theory in an experiential learning exercise to change a personal belief or behaviour.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Cognition & Culture
This module offers an overview of what cognition is and the ways it can be applied in different real-world contexts.
Assessments are designed to enable you to work in groups and individually to present an argument for a non-technical audience. Teamwork and clear communication are essential skills in graduate-level employment.
You will be assessed via: * Group poster designed for a public audience summarising a method in the psychology of cognition and culture * Individual oral presentation of individual difference on aspect of perception, attention or action.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Life And Society
This module offers an introduction to the self and interactions with others using social and developmental psychological theories.
Assessments are designed to ensure that you have grasped key concepts and that you can apply your learning in the form of a policy briefing paper. These policy briefs are frequently written in government agencies, businesses and non-government organisations to enable readers to understand how to take evidence-based actions on a particular issue.
You will be assessed via: * In-person exam * Policy brief on the first 1001 days of life

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Identity, Agency & Environment
This Semester 1 module will enable you to develop critical thinking skills through various topics:
Hello students of Identity Agency Environment 1 (IAE1) - this module is subtitled Critical Thinking. Welcome to the module and to your new year at Goldsmiths.
Every week this module will introduce you to a new, compelling, topical subject in a lecture, followed by interdisciplinary seminar groups, where you will explore your critical thinking capacities and engage with peers in discussions about topics you are presented with.
Your assessment at the close of the semester will be to respond critically to one of these topics in a way that feels purposeful and useful for you. You might decide to express your ideas about the topic of your choice by writing an essay, song, poem or composition, or by making a podcast, film, or designing a poster.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Applications of Psychological Research
This Semester 2 module will enable you to critically evaluate psychological research findings and understand the motivation and practical issues involved in the planning and conduct of that research, from the perspective of investigators and research participants.
You will be assessed via: * Participation in research studies * A Blog or pre-recorded video for a non-expert audience—

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
References

Amabile, T. M., Mueller, J. S., Simpson, W. B., Hadley, C. N., Kramer, S. J., & Fleming, L. (2002). Time pressure and creativity in organizations: A longitudinal field study. Harvard Business School Working Paper, 02-073.
Brown, T. (2009). Change by design: How design thinking transforms organizations and inspires innovation. HarperCollins.
Dweck, C. S. (2006). Mindset: The new psychology of success. Random House.
Edmondson, A. (1999). Psychological safety and learning behavior in work teams. Administrative Science Quarterly, 44(2), 350-383. https://doi.org/10.2307/2666999
Tuckman, B. W. (1965). Developmental sequence in small groups. Psychological Bulletin, 63(6), 384-399. https://doi.org/10.1037/h0022100
Wujec, T. (2010, February). Build a tower, build a team [Video]. TED Conferences. https://www.ted.com/talks/tom_wujec_build_a_tower_build_a_team
Yerkes, R. M., & Dodson, J. D. (1908). The relation of strength of stimulus to rapidity of habit-formation. Journal of Comparative Neurology and Psychology, 18(5), 459-482. https://doi.org/10.1002/cne.920180503

Psychological Profiling (in all it’s guises)
All students are welcome to join in (current and maybe future!)
@ForensicGold on X.com
https://www.gold.ac.uk/forensic-psychology-unit/

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Thank you
Any Questions?

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
What is People-Watching?


“I like to watch people. Sometimes I ride the subway all day and look at them and listen to them. I just want to figure out who they are and what they want and where they’re going.”



— Ray Bradbury, Fahrenheit 451



Start by asking students if they’ve ever people-watched
Explain that this common pastime is actually a sophisticated cognitive process

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
More Than Just a Pastime
People-watching is central to our social existence

We observe others to gather information
We form impressions within seconds
Our brains are wired to analyze social interactions
These impressions affect how we interact with others



Emphasize that people-watching isn’t just entertainment
It’s a fundamental cognitive skill that helps us navigate our social world
Ask students when they might people-watch (cafes, airports, school hallways)

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Science of “Third-Party Encounters”


Traditional Research

Focused on impressions of isolated individuals
Usually just faces or single people
Missed the complexity of social interactions


New Research Direction

Studies how we observe interactions between others
Views interactions as the unit of analysis
Recognizes the richness of encounter-based impressions




Explain that “Third-Party Encounters” (TPEs) is the scientific term for watching people interact
Mention that this is a relatively new and exciting area of research

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Brain Game: Reading Social Clues
What clues do we use when people-watching? Let’s see how many you can identify!

Physical appearances and facial expressions
Body language and proximity
Gestures and eye contact
Speaking patterns and tone
Actions and reactions
Can you think of others?



Make this interactive - ask students to volunteer additional cues they use
Have them discuss with a partner how they “read” other people

title: The Science of People-Watching
section: What Can We Actually Tell from Watching?
text:
What Can We Actually Tell from Watching?

Joint vs. independent actions
Power dynamics and social status
Level of intimacy and rapport
Emotional states and attitudes
Type of relationship (strangers, friends, family)
Cultural norms and violations



Explain each item with examples relevant to high school students
E.g., how can you tell who’s popular, who’s dating, who’s arguing?

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Our Brains on People-Watching
Three brain networks work together:

Person Perception Network: Processes faces and bodies
Action Perception Network: Understands actions and movements
Mentalizing Network: Interprets mental states and intentions



Explain in simple terms how our brains have specialized systems for social perception
Compare to having different apps that work together on a phone

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Marketing Connection


Companies like Coca-Cola use our people-watching instincts in advertisements:

Show intimate moments between people
Trigger our social analysis systems
Make us feel connected to the product
Leverage our desire to be part of positive interactions





Coca-Cola ad showing social connection





Discuss how ads often show people interacting rather than just the product
Ask students to recall ads that use social scenarios to sell products

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Quick Activity: Spot the Relationship
As I show each image, write down:

What type of relationship do you think these people have?
How do you know?
What clues are you using?



Show 3-4 images of different interactions (friends, romantic partners, strangers, etc.)
Have students jot down observations and discuss with a partner
Then discuss as a group, noting common patterns in observations

title: The Science of People-Watching
section: Are We Actually Good at People-Watching?
text:
Are We Actually Good at People-Watching?


When we’re accurate:

Judging whether people know each other
Detecting romantic interest
Recognizing power differences
Identifying basic emotions


When we make mistakes:

Overrelying on stereotypes
Misreading cultural differences
Assuming internal states from external behavior
Projecting our own expectations




Discuss why we might misinterpret what we see
Connect to real-life experiences students might have had

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Social Intelligence Hypothesis


Did social complexity drive brain evolution?

Humans have uniquely complex social structures
Keeping track of many relationships requires cognitive power
Our large brains may have evolved partly to handle social computations
People-watching skills appear very early in development





Brain evolution illustration





Explain how even 6-month-old infants show surprise at “irrational” social interactions
Connect to evolutionary advantages of understanding social dynamics

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Real-World Applications


Clinical Psychology

Assessing social-cognitive functioning
Diagnosing conditions like autism
Designing better therapies


Education

Improving observational learning
Understanding classroom dynamics
Designing better social skills programs


Technology

Training AI to understand human interactions
Developing more natural robots
Improving virtual reality experiences




Emphasize the many practical applications of this research
Connect to potential career paths students might find interesting

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
People-Watching Skills Challenge
How can you become a better people-watcher?

Practice observing without jumping to conclusions
Notice patterns across different situations
Consider cultural and contextual factors
Be aware of your own biases and expectations
Look for details in behavior and responses



Frame people-watching as a skill that can be developed
Emphasize the ethical aspects (respect for privacy, avoiding judgmentalism)

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Future of People-Watching Research
Exciting new directions:

Cross-cultural studies of social perception
How virtual interactions change our people-watching abilities
Neural mechanisms of real-time social analysis
How our social perceptions influence our behavior
Using VR to study encounter-based impressions



Highlight that this is a growing field with many unanswered questions
Mention opportunities for students interested in psychology, neuroscience, or sociology

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Why This Matters
People-watching is more than entertainment:

It helps us understand complex social dynamics
It provides a window into how our brains process social information
It reveals biases and cultural differences in perception
It connects to fundamental questions about what makes us human
It has countless applications in the real world



Wrap up by emphasizing the significance of this research
Connect back to students’ everyday experiences

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Try It Yourself!
Mini-experiment for the next week:

Spend 10 minutes people-watching in a public place
Record your observations and impressions
Note what specific cues led to your conclusions
Reflect on any assumptions you might have made
Compare notes with friends - did they notice the same things?



Provide a simple, ethical activity students can try
Emphasize respectful observation in public places only
Suggest they might notice new things after this presentation

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Thank You!


Questions to consider:

How might people-watching skills differ across cultures?
How might social media change how we read social cues?
What ethical considerations should people-watchers keep in mind?
How might technology like AR glasses change people-watching?





QR code linking to research





End with discussion questions
Provide resources for students who want to learn more

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
References

Barasz, K., & Kim, T. (2022). Editorial: A field guide to people-watching. Current Opinion in Psychology, 45, 101301.
Quadflieg, S., & Penton-Voak, I. (2017). The Emerging Science of People-Watching: Forming Impressions From Third-Party Encounters. Current Directions in Psychological Science, 26(4), 383-389.
Place, S. S., Todd, P. M., Zhuang, J., Penke, L., & Asendorpf, J. B. (2012). Judging romantic interest of others from thin slices is a cross-cultural ability. Evolution and Human Behavior, 33, 547-550.
Manera, V., Del Giudice, M., Bara, B. G., Verfailie, K., & Becchio, C. (2011). The second-agent effect: communicative gestures increase the likelihood of perceiving a second agent. PLoS One, 6, e22650.



Acknowledge the researchers whose work formed the basis of the presentation

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Methodological Challenge

How do researchers systematically study something as complex and natural as people-watching?



Explain that studying social perception requires specialized methods
Highlight the challenge of examining an automatic process we usually do unconsciously
Note that researchers had to develop innovative approaches to study this phenomenon

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Research Paradigm Shift


Traditional Approach



Single face studies



Single faces or individuals
Static images
Isolated traits or emotions
Decontextualized


TPE Approach 

Multiple people interacting
Dynamic exchanges
Relational qualities
Contextualized interactions




Explain how studying dyads required a completely different experimental approach
Note that this represents a significant methodological innovation in social psychology

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Stimuli Toolkit
Researchers use a variety of stimuli to study people-watching:


Static 

Photographs
Paintings
Drawings


Dynamic 

Video clips
Animations
Live interactions


Abstracted 

Point light displays
Stick figures
Silhouettes




Explain each type of stimulus and why researchers might choose one over another
Point light displays especially show our ability to read social information from minimal cues
Note how abstracted stimuli help isolate motion and configuration information from identity

title: The Science of People-Watching
section: Point Light Displays: A Technical Deep Dive
text:
Point Light Displays: A Technical Deep Dive


How they work: * Actors wear reflective markers on joints * Movements are recorded in darkness * Only points of light are visible * Removes all identity cues * Isolates pure motion information
The surprising finding: We can determine social relationships from just moving dots!




Point light display example





Explain this is a powerful technique originally developed for studying biological motion
The fact we can read social relationships from such minimal stimuli shows how sensitive our social perception systems are
Used in the research by Manera et al. (2011)

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Eye-Tracking Methods


What researchers track: * Fixation patterns between interacting people * Gaze switches between interaction partners * Time spent looking at different body parts * Pupil dilation (indicating emotional response) * Scan path analysis (the sequence of looking)




Eye tracking heatmap example





Explain that eye-tracking reveals what information people are extracting during social observation
Studies by Villani et al. showed observers continuously look back and forth between interaction partners
This methodology helps identify what visual cues people use when forming impressions

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Brain Imaging Techniques


fMRI Studies Reveal:



fMRI brain scan



Three integrated neural networks
Increased activity for joint vs. independent actions
Specialized brain regions for social context processing


The Three Networks:



Brain networks schematic



Person Perception Network (PPN)
Action Perception Network (APN)
Mentalizing Network (MN)




Explain these networks form the neural foundation of people-watching
PPN analyzes faces and bodies
APN interprets actions and movements
MN attributes mental states and intentions
Describe how fMRI shows these networks activate more strongly during observations of interacting vs. non-interacting people

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Experimental Paradigms


Encounter Categorization Task

Participants classify interactions into types
Measures accuracy and response time
Example categories:

Cooperative vs. competitive
Formal vs. intimate
Dominant vs. equal status



Encounter Prediction Task

Participants predict how an interaction will unfold
View partial information (beginning of interaction)
Predict next actions or relationship outcomes
Tests understanding of social dynamics




These paradigms measure how accurately people can “read” social situations
Explain that reaction time gives insight into automatic vs. deliberate processing
Connect to real-world situation where we need to quickly assess social dynamics

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The “Thin Slices” Methodology


How it works: * Observers view brief (10-30 second) clips of interactions * Make judgments about relationships, traits, or outcomes * Judgments are compared to actual outcomes or self-reports * Measures the accuracy of rapid social perception
Key research question: How much social information can we extract from minimal exposure?




People interacting at party





Explain that “thin slices” refers to brief samples of behavior
This method has shown we need surprisingly little information to form accurate impressions
Place et al. (2012) used this to study romantic interest detection across cultures

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Visual Cue Analysis
Researchers isolate and manipulate specific visual cues:


Physical proximity 
Facial expressions 

Body orientation 
Motion synchrony 



Explain how researchers systematically manipulate one variable while controlling others
Distance studies (proxemics) show we judge relationships partly by how close people stand
Synchrony studies reveal we detect even subtle coordination between interaction partners

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Experimental Design: Biernieri’s Classic Study


Methodology: 1. Filmed dyads of strangers having conversations 2. Participants rated their own felt rapport 3. Observers watched silent video clips 4. Observers rated perceived rapport 5. Compared self-reports vs. observer judgments 6. Analyzed which visual cues predicted each
Key finding: Observers relied on smiles, but participants’ ratings were linked to physical proximity




People in conversation





This 1996 study was groundbreaking in revealing the mismatch between perceived and felt rapport
Explains why we sometimes misread social situations - we rely on visible cues that may not be diagnostic
Connect to everyday experience of misjudging whether people are enjoying a conversation

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Cross-Cultural Research Methods


Research Questions: * Are some social perceptions universal? * How do cultural norms affect interpretation? * Which cues are culturally specific? * Can people accurately read interactions from other cultures?

Methodology: * Show identical interactions to people from different cultures * Compare perception accuracy across cultures * Analyze culture-specific interpretation biases * Test for universal vs. culture-specific cues



Place et al. (2012) found that detecting romantic interest is a cross-cultural ability
Some social cues appear to be universal, while others are culturally specific
This methodology helps separate innate from learned aspects of social perception

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
The Two-Strategy Hypothesis


How do we process social interactions?
Feature-Based Processing * Extract specific visual components * Analyze individual cues (e.g., number of smiles) * Process components separately * Build up interpretation from parts
Template-Based Processing * Compare to stored patterns of typical interactions * Process interactions holistically * Use prior expectations to guide perception * Recognize patterns from minimal information




Social interaction analysis diagram





Explain that researchers debate which strategy is primary
Evidence suggests we may use both strategies at different processing stages
Template approach explains how we recognize interactions even from minimal cues
Feature approach explains how we analyze specific aspects of interactions

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Developmental Research Methods


With Infants & Toddlers: * Looking time paradigms * Violation-of-expectation method * Preferential looking tasks * Action imitation studies * Measures: gaze duration, surprise, preference

Research Findings: * 6-month-olds notice “irrational” interactions * 12-month-olds have expectations about social goals * 18-month-olds imitate observed interactions * Social perception develops before language



Explain each methodology (e.g., babies look longer at unexpected events)
These methods reveal that social perception is present very early in development
Findings suggest some aspects of people-watching may be innate or develop very early
Gredebäck & Melinder’s research shows infants’ sophisticated social understanding

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Clinical Applications & Methods


Comparative Studies: * Compare clinical vs. typical populations * Diagnose social-cognitive differences * Identify specific processing differences * Design targeted interventions
Example: Autism studies show differences in: * Eye movement patterns * Neural activation patterns * Types of social cues utilized




Clinical assessment setup





Explain how these methods help understand conditions with social perception differences
Byrge et al. (2015) showed distinct neural patterns in autism during interaction observation
These findings help develop better assessment tools and interventions
Connect to potential career paths in clinical psychology or neuroscience

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Virtual Reality Methods


Advantages: * Precise control over social scenarios * Manipulation of specific social variables * Immersive, ecological validity * Replicable across participants * Can track behavior in realistic contexts




VR research setup


Growing area of TPE research!



Explain how VR allows researchers to create controlled but realistic social scenarios
VR can place participants within interactions rather than just observing them
Emerging methodology that combines control with ecological validity
Connect to potential future research directions

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Computational Modeling


How It Works: * Create computational models of social perception * Test which features are most diagnostic * Simulate different processing strategies * Compare model performance to human performance * Identify minimal features needed for accurate perception
Questions Addressed: * Which visual features are most informative? * How do we integrate different social cues? * How does prior knowledge influence perception?




Computational model diagram





Explain that computational models help test theories about how people process social information
These models can reveal which strategies are most efficient and accurate
Modeling approaches help bridge psychology and computer science
Connect to AI and machine learning applications

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Future Methodological Frontiers

Hyperscanning: Simultaneous brain recording from multiple individuals
Natural Language Processing: Analyzing verbal content of interactions
Machine Learning Applications: Training computers to recognize social dynamics
Mobile Eye-Tracking: Studying social perception in real-world environments
Digital Phenotyping: Using smartphone data to assess social perception abilities



Hyperscanning studies neural synchronization between interacting individuals
Mobile methods allow studying social perception in natural environments
These cutting-edge methods will further advance our understanding of people-watching
Connect to potential research careers and interdisciplinary approaches

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Technical Challenge: Design Your Study


You are a social psychologist studying how teens detect popularity based on observed interactions.
What would you include in your research design? * What stimuli would you use? * What measures would you employ? * What variables would you manipulate? * How would you assess accuracy? * What technologies would you incorporate?




Teens interacting





Make this interactive - have students discuss in small groups
Connect to real-world high school social dynamics
Encourage creative thinking about methodology
Emphasize that good research requires careful design

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Methods Integration: A Case Study


Research Question: How do we detect cooperative vs. competitive relationships?
Multi-method Approach: 1. Eye-tracking (what cues we look at) 2. fMRI (neural processing differences) 3. Behavioral measures (accuracy & reaction time) 4. Computational modeling (processing strategies)




Integration of methods diagram





Explain how combining multiple methods provides stronger evidence
Each method addresses different aspects of the research question
Integration allows researchers to connect neural, cognitive, and behavioral levels
Strong research programs use complementary methods

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
Thank You!


Key Takeaways: * People-watching research uses sophisticated methodologies * Multiple techniques provide complementary insights * The field combines psychology, neuroscience, and computer science * These methods reveal how we make sense of our social world * New technologies continue to advance our understanding




Social interaction research





Wrap up by emphasizing the sophisticated methodologies used in this research
Connect to potential career pathways in psychology, neuroscience, or data science
Invite questions about specific methodologies

title: The Science of People-Watching
text:
References

Barasz, K., & Kim, T. (2022). Editorial: A field guide to people-watching. Current Opinion in Psychology, 45, 101301.
Quadflieg, S., & Penton-Voak, I. (2017). The Emerging Science of People-Watching: Forming Impressions From Third-Party Encounters. Current Directions in Psychological Science, 26(4), 383-389.
Bernieri, F. J., Gillis, J. S., Davis, J. M., & Grahe, J. E. (1996). Dyad rapport and the accuracy of its judgment across situations: A Lens Model analysis. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 71, 110-129.
Manera, V., Del Giudice, M., Bara, B. G., Verfailie, K., & Becchio, C. (2011). The second-agent effect: communicative gestures increase the likelihood of perceiving a second agent. PLoS One, 6, e22650.
Villani, D., Morganti, F., Cipresso, P., Ruggi, S., Riva, G., & Gilli, G. (2015). Visual exploration patterns of human figures in action. Frontiers in Psychology, doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01636.



Acknowledge the researchers whose methodological innovations advanced this field

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Dr. Gordon Wright

Lecturer in Deception, Mind-reading and People-Watching


Chief Mischief Officer - LittleMonkeyLab

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: I’m very sorry…

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Little Monkey

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Deception - Key Questions

Why do we lie?
Who lies? How much?
How do we do it?

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Why we lie

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Who lies and how often?

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
But is it so bad?

Well I argue not
We saw out little monkey tricking his co-monkeys out of a tasty bird’s egg
That’s right up there with animals that use tools

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Dunbar’s Number

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Introducing Mind-space


Every person’s mind exists in a multidimensional space
It’s like the multiverse, but for brains!
Minds are mapped based on traits, abilities, and quirks
YOU are constantly navigating this mind-boggling terrain

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
The Power of Mind-space


Not just abstract theory - the key to unlocking human behavior!
Every time you:

Size someone up
Predict their actions
Wonder “What were they thinking?!”

You’re tapping into the awesome power of Mind-space!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
section: For any AI geeks out there… 💛
text:
For any AI geeks out there… 💛

It’s essentially the same idea as embeddings in vectorspace in LLMs
But we do it WAY better, and potentially faster!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
What’s the point?

It’s not just really cool (it is!)
It could offer us new ways to understand variability in Social Cognitive ability
And understand some of the ‘magic’ abilities we share with cheeky monkeys

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Systematic Observation in Natural Settings

Street Psychology
Observing behavior without interference
Identifying patterns and anomalies
Real-life Psychological Profiling
Inferring meaning and motive in everyday behaviour

text:
